column3:
Though something is clearly going wrong in boost cross-compilation, 
- the host platform should not influence in any way what gets passed to the target compiler
- according to `man gcc`, m32/m64 is _only_ supported on "i386 and x86-64" so I think it would make sense to make the condition the other way around instead of a platform blacklist when _not_ to pass it

Arguably an upstream issue and
Looks like this has been fixed upstream in https://github.com/boostorg/build/commit/cbddcde5953c8e51f52bfe612f53d0b779ade5f3\n

Thanks @fanquake . Seems what they did is:

```
-            if $(arch) != arm
+            if $(arch) = power || $(arch) = sparc || $(arch) = x86
```

Which is better as it explicitly defines which platforms can use -mXX (didn't know about power and sparc).

An alternative would be to bump boost to 1.59 (which includes this). Seems to work fine in local testing.
@theuni What do you think is best here?\n
